head.title: Constraints on Cosmological Parameters from the LyŒ± Forest Power Spectrum and COBE-DMR

article.h1: Constraints on Cosmological Parameters from the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha Forest Power Spectrum and COBE-DMR

div.p: We combine COBE-DMR measurements of cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropy with a recent measurement of the mass power spectrum at redshift z=2.5ùëß2.5italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5z=2.5 from LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest data to derive constraints on cosmological parameters and test the inflationary cold dark matter (CDM) scenario of structure formation. By treating the inflationary spectral index nùëõitalic-nn as a free parameter, we are able to find successful fits to the COBE and LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest constraints in Œ©m=1subscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}=1 models with and without massive neutrinos and in low-Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} models with and without a cosmological constant. Within each class of model, the combination of COBE and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constrains a parameter combination of the form Œ©m‚Å¢hŒ±‚Å¢nŒ≤‚Å¢Œ©bŒ≥subscriptŒ©ùëösuperscript‚ÑéùõºsuperscriptùëõùõΩsuperscriptsubscriptŒ©ùëèùõæOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}h^{\alpha}n^{\beta}\Omega_{b}^{\gamma}, with different indices for each case. This new constraint breaks some of the degeneracies in cosmological parameter determinations from other measurements of large scale structure and CMB anisotropy. The LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) provides the first measurement of the slope of the linear mass power spectrum on ‚àºsimilar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\;Mpc scales, ŒΩ=-2.25¬±0.18ùúàplus-or-minus2.250.18italic-nu RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.25 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.18\nu=-2.25\pm 0.18, and it confirms a basic prediction of the inflationary CDM scenario: an approximately scale-invariant spectrum of primeval fluctuations (n‚âà1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1n\approx 1) modulated by a transfer function that bends P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) towards kn-4superscriptùëòùëõ4italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk^{n-4} on small scales. Considering additional observational data, we find that COBE-normalized, Œ©m=1subscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}=1 models that match the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) do not match the observed masses of rich galaxy clusters and that low-Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} models with a cosmological constant provide the best overall fit to the available data, even without the direct evidence for cosmic acceleration from Type Ia supernovae. With our fiducial parameter choices, the flat, low-Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{m} models that match COBE and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) also match recent measurements of small scale CMB anisotropy. Modest improvements in the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) measurement could greatly restrict the allowable region of parameter space for CDM models, constrain the contribution of tensor fluctuations to CMB anisotropy, and achieve a more stringent test of the current consensus model of structure formation.

div.p: Cosmological models based on cold dark matter (CDM) and simple versions of inflation have had considerable success in accounting for the origin of cosmic structure. In this class of models, the primordial density fluctuations are Gaussian distributed, and the shape of their power spectrum is determined by a small number of physical parameters that describe the inflationary fluctuations themselves and the material contents of the universe. For specified cosmological parameters, the measurement of cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropies by the COBE-DMR experiment (smoot92 ; bennett96 ) fixes the amplitude of the matter power spectrum on large scales with an uncertainty of ‚àº20%similar-toabsentpercent20RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:20 POSTFIX:percent\sim 20\% (e.g., bunn97 ). In this paper, we combine the COBE normalization with a recent measurement of the matter power spectrum by Croft et al.¬†(1999b, hereafter CWPHK) to test the inflation+CDM scenario and constrain its physical parameters. A modified version of the method developed here is applied to a more recent power spectrum measurement by Croft et al.¬†(2001).

CWPHK infer the mass power spectrum P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) from measurements of LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest absorption in the light of background quasars, at a mean absorption redshift z‚âà2.5ùëß2.5italic-z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:2.5z\approx 2.5. The method, introduced by Croft et al.¬†(1998), is based on the physical picture of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest that has emerged in recent years from 3-dimensional, hydrodynamic cosmological simulations and related analytic models (e.g., cen94 ; Zhang (Anninos); hernquist96 ; bi97 ; Hui (Gnedin)). By focusing on the absorption from diffuse intergalactic gas in mildly non-linear structures, this method sidesteps the complicated theoretical problem of biased galaxy formation; it directly estimates the linear theory mass power spectrum (over a limited range of scales) under the assumption of Gaussian initial conditions. Because the observational units are km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, the CWPHK measurement probes somewhat different comoving scales for different cosmological parameters: Œª‚â°2‚Å¢œÄ/k=2-12‚Å¢h-1‚Å¢MpcùúÜ2ùúãùëò212superscript‚Ñé1Mpcitalic-lambda RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:2 italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:12 italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Mpc\lambda\equiv 2\pi/k=2-12{h^{-1}{\rm Mpc}\;} for Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}=1, Œª=3-16‚Å¢h-1‚Å¢MpcùúÜ316superscript‚Ñé1Mpcitalic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:16 italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Mpc\lambda=3-16{h^{-1}{\rm Mpc}\;} for Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}=0.55 and Œ©ŒõsubscriptŒ©ŒõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{\Lambda}}=0, and Œª=4-22‚Å¢h-1‚Å¢MpcùúÜ422superscript‚Ñé1Mpcitalic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:22 italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Mpc\lambda=4-22{h^{-1}{\rm Mpc}\;} for Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}=0.4 and Œ©ŒõsubscriptŒ©ŒõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{\Lambda}}=0.6 (h‚â°H0/100‚Å¢km‚Å¢s-1‚Å¢Mpc-1‚Ñésubscriptùêª0100kmsuperscripts1superscriptMpc1italic-h RELOP:equivalent-to italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:100 km s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Mpc POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endh\equiv H_{0}/100\;{\rm{km\;s^{-1}\;}}\;{\rm Mpc}^{-1}). CWPHK determine the logarithmic slope of P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) on these scales with an uncertainty ‚àº0.2similar-toabsent0.2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.2\sim 0.2 and the amplitude with an uncertainty ‚àº35%similar-toabsentpercent35RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:35 POSTFIX:percent\sim 35\%. The extensive tests on simulations in Croft et al.¬†(1998) and CWPHK suggest that the statistical uncertainties quoted here dominate over systematic errors in the method itself, though the measurement does depend on the assumption of Gaussian primordial fluctuations and on the broad physical picture of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest described in the references above. For brevity, we will usually refer to the CWPHK determination of the mass power spectrum as ‚Äúthe LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k).‚Äù

In the next Section, we discuss our choice of the parameter space for inflationary CDM models. The core of the paper is Section 3, where we combine the COBE normalization with the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) to identify acceptable regions of the CDM parameter space. We focus on four representative models: a low density (Œ©m<1subscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}<1) open model, a low density flat model with a cosmological constant, and Einstein-de Sitter (Œ©m=1subscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}=1) models with pure CDM and with a mixture of CDM and hot dark matter. Because different parameters have nearly degenerate influences on the predicted LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), we are able to summarize our results in terms of simple equations that constrain combinations of these parameters. In Section 4, we consider other observational constraints that can break these degeneracies, such as the cluster mass function, the peculiar velocity power spectrum, the shape of the galaxy power spectrum, and the CMB anisotropy power spectrum. We review our conclusions in Section 5.

In simple inflationary models, the power spectrum of density fluctuations in the linear regime can be well approximated as a power law, P‚Å¢(k)‚àùknproportional-toùëÉùëòsuperscriptùëòùëõitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:) RELOP:proportional-to italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP(k)\propto k^{n} (where n=1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1 is the scale-invariant spectrum), multiplied by the square of a transfer function T‚Å¢(k)ùëáùëòitalic-T OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)T(k) that depends on the relative energy densities of components with different equations of state. We will assume the standard radiation background (microwave background photons and three species of light neutrinos) and consider as other possible components cold dark matter, baryons, a ‚Äúcosmological constant‚Äù vacuum energy, and neutrinos with a non-zero rest mass in the few eV range. Within this class of models, the shape of the power spectrum is therefore determined by the parameters nùëõitalic-nn, Œ©CDMsubscriptŒ©CDMOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start CDM POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\rm CDM}, Œ©bsubscriptŒ©ùëèOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{b}, Œ©ŒõsubscriptŒ©ŒõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\Lambda}, Œ©ŒΩsubscriptŒ©ùúàOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\nu}, and h‚Ñéitalic-hh (since œÅx=Œ©x‚Å¢œÅc‚àùŒ©x‚Å¢h2subscriptùúåùë•subscriptŒ©ùë•subscriptùúåùëêproportional-tosubscriptŒ©ùë•superscript‚Ñé2italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:proportional-to Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\rho_{x}=\Omega_{x}\rho_{c}\propto\Omega_{x}h^{2}). In place of Œ©bsubscriptŒ©ùëèOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{b} and Œ©CDMsubscriptŒ©CDMOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start CDM POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\rm CDM}, we use the parameters

div.p: which is constrained by light-element abundances through big bang nucleosynthesis (walker91 ), and

div.p: Once the cosmological parameters are specified, normalizing to the results of the COBE-DMR experiment determines the amplitude of P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). For inflation models with n<1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1n<1, the COBE normalization can also be affected by the presence of tensor fluctuations (gravity waves). We consider normalizations with no tensor contribution and normalizations with the quadrupole tensor-to-scalar ratio T/S=7‚Å¢(1-n)ùëáùëÜ71ùëõitalic-T MULOP:divide italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:7 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-n CLOSE:)T/S=7(1-n) predicted by simple power law inflation models (e.g., davis92 ), but we do not consider arbitrary tensor contributions. We compute the COBE-normalized, linear theory, matter power spectrum P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) using the convenient and accurate fitting formulas of Eisenstein & Hu (1999), with the normalization procedures of Bunn & White (1997) for all flat cases and for the open case without a tensor contribution and Hu & White (1997) for the open case with a tensor contribution.

There are plausible variants of this family of inflationary CDM models that we do not analyze in this paper, because we lack the tools to easily calculate their predictions and because they would make our parameter space intractably larger. Prominent among these variants are models with a time-varying scalar field, a.k.a. ‚Äúquintessence‚Äù (e.g., peebles88 ; wang98 ), models in which the energy of the radiation background has been boosted above its standard value by a decaying particle species, a.k.a. ‚ÄúœÑùúèitalic-tau\tauCDM‚Äù (e.g., bond91 ), and models in which inflation produces a power spectrum with broken scale invariance (e.g., kates95 ). Given the observational evidence for a negative pressure component from Type Ia supernovae (riess98 ; perlmutter99 ), the quintessence family might be especially interesting to explore in future work.

In sum, the free parameters of our family of cosmological models are Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{m}, h‚Ñéitalic-hh, nùëõitalic-nn, Bùêµitalic-BB, Œ©ŒΩsubscriptŒ©ùúàOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\nu}, Œ©ŒõsubscriptŒ©ŒõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\Lambda}, and T/SùëáùëÜitalic-T MULOP:divide italic-ST/S. We allow Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{m}, h‚Ñéitalic-hh, nùëõitalic-nn, Bùêµitalic-BB, and Œ©ŒΩsubscriptŒ©ùúàOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\nu} to assume a continuous range of values. For Œ©ŒõsubscriptŒ©ŒõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\Lambda} and T/SùëáùëÜitalic-T MULOP:divide italic-ST/S we consider only two discrete options: Œ©Œõ=0subscriptŒ©Œõ0Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Omega_{\Lambda}=0 or 1-Œ©m1subscriptŒ©ùëöNUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end1-\Omega_{m}, and T/S=0ùëáùëÜ0italic-T MULOP:divide italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T/S=0 or 7‚Å¢(1-n)71ùëõNUMBER:7 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-n CLOSE:)7(1-n).

section.h2: 3 Cosmological Parameters and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†Forest P(k)

div.p: To organize our discussion and guide our analysis, we focus on variations about four fiducial models, each motivated by a combination of theoretical and observational considerations. The fiducial models are a flat cold dark matter model with a non-zero cosmological constant (ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM), an open cold dark matter model with no cosmological constant (OCDM), an Œ©m=1subscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Omega_{m}=1 cold dark matter model with a significantly ‚Äútilted‚Äù inflationary spectrum (TCDM), and an Œ©m=1subscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Omega_{m}=1 model with a mixture of cold and hot dark matter (CHDM).

Figure 1:
Power spectra of the fiducial models (smooth curves) compared to the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) determined by CWPHK (filled circles). Upper panels show models with no tensor fluctuations and lower panels show models with tensor fluctuations; the right hand panels zoom in on the range of wavenumbers probed by the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). The error bar on the open circle shows an overall normalization uncertainty in the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k); at the 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma level all of the points can shift up or down coherently by this amount. Model parameters are listed in Table 1.

div.p: Figure 1 compares the power spectra of our fiducial models to the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), shown as the filled circles with error bars. Note that the overall normalization of the data points is uncertain; at the 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma level they can shift up or down coherently by the amount indicated by the error bar on the open circle (see CWPHK for details). The COBE normalization itself has a 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainty of approximately 20% in P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), roughly half of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) normalization uncertainty. Panels (a) and (c) show the fiducial models with and without tensors, respectively, over a wide range of wavenumber. Panels (b) and (d) focus on the range of wavenumbers probed by the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). Our first major result is already evident from Figure 1: all of the fiducial models reproduce the observed LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). Each model has a single adjustable parameter, the spectral index nùëõitalic-nn, so their success in reproducing both the amplitude and slope of P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) is an important confirmation of a generic prediction of the inflationary CDM scenario, a point we will return to shortly.

Within the precision and dynamic range of the CWPHK measurement, the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) can be adequately described by a power law. CWPHK find

div.p: Here Œî2‚Å¢(k)superscriptŒî2ùëòDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k) is the contribution to the density variance per unit interval of ln‚Å°kùëòOPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-k\ln k, and kpsubscriptùëòùëùitalic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{p} is a ‚Äúpivot‚Äù wavenumber near the middle of the range probed by the data.

In each panel of Figures¬†2 and¬†3, the central star shows the best fit values of Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}) and ŒΩùúàitalic-nu\nu quoted above, and the two large concentric circles show the 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma (68%) and 2‚Å¢œÉ2ùúéNUMBER:2 italic-sigma2\sigma (95%) confidence contours on the parameter values. The calculation of these confidence contours is described in detail in Section 5 of CWPHK. Briefly, the likelihood distribution for the slope, ŒΩùúàitalic-nu\nu, is derived by fitting the power law form (eq.¬†3) to the P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) data points, using their covariance matrix. The likelihood distribution for the amplitude, Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}), is obtained by convolving the distributions calculated from two separate sources of uncertainty involved in the P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) normalization. The joint confidence contours on the two parameters are obtained by multiplying together the two independent likelihood distributions. The 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma and 2‚Å¢œÉ2ùúéNUMBER:2 italic-sigma2\sigma contours correspond to changes in -2‚Å¢loge‚Å°‚Ñí2subscriptùëí‚ÑíADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-L-2\log_{e}\cal{L} from its best fit value of 2.302.30NUMBER:2.302.30 and 6.176.17NUMBER:6.176.17, respectively, where ‚Ñí‚Ñícaligraphic-L\cal{L} is the likelihood.

The open circular point near the middle of each panel of these figures shows the fiducial model‚Äôs prediction of Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}) and ŒΩùúàitalic-nu\nu. ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM, OCDM, and TCDM models without tensors appear in the left column of Figure¬†2, the corresponding models with tensors appear in the right column of Figure¬†2, and the CHDM model appears in Figure¬†3. As expected from Figure¬†1, the fiducial model predictions lie well within the 68% confidence contour in all cases. The 20% COBE normalization uncertainty adds a log‚Å°(1.2)‚âà0.081.20.08OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( NUMBER:1.2 CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.08\log(1.2)\approx 0.08 error bar to the predicted value of log‚Å°Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùOPFUNCTION:logarithm Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\log\Delta^{2}(k_{p}), which we have not included in the plots. Because this uncertainty is small (once added in quadrature) compared to the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) uncertainty itself, we have ignored it in the analysis of this paper. With a higher precision LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest measurement, it would be important to include the COBE normalization uncertainty as an additional source of statistical error.

Parameter changes have similar effects in all of the models, and these effects can be easily understood by considering the physics that determines the shape and normalization of the matter power spectrum. The CDM transfer function has a single fundamental scale c‚Å¢teqùëêsubscriptùë°eqitalic-c italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eq POSTSUBSCRIPT:endct_{m eq} determined by the size of the horizon at the time of matter-radiation equality; this scale is roughly the wavelength at which the power spectrum turns over. Increasing h‚Ñéitalic-hh, and hence the matter density œÅm‚àùŒ©m‚Å¢h2proportional-tosubscriptùúåùëösubscriptŒ©ùëösuperscript‚Ñé2italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:proportional-to Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endho_{m}\propto{\Omega_{m}}h^{2}, moves matter-radiation equality to higher redshift and lower teqsubscriptùë°eqitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eq POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{m eq}, shifting the model power spectrum towards smaller scales (to the right in Figure¬†1). This horizontal shift, combined with an upward vertical shift to maintain the COBE normalization on large scales, increases the amplitude of P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) on LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest scales and translates a shallower (higher ŒΩùúàitalic-nu
u) part of the spectrum to kpsubscriptùëòùëùitalic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{p}. Increasing Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} also lowers teqsubscriptùë°eqitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eq POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{m eq} and therefore has a similar effect. Open models are more sensitive than flat models to changes in Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} because the integrated Sachs-Wolfe effect makes a greater contribution to large scale CMB anisotropies (sachs67 ; Hu (Sugiyama)). Increasing Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} reduces the integrated Sachs-Wolfe effect and hence increases the matter fluctuation amplitude implied by COBE, shifting the power spectrum vertically upward. The value of Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}) is sensitive to the spectral index nùëõitalic-nn because of the very long lever arm between the COBE normalization scale and the scale of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest measurement. A small decrease in nùëõitalic-nn produces an equally small decrease in ŒΩùúàitalic-nu
u but a large decrease in Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}). The fluctuation amplitude is even more sensitive to nùëõitalic-nn in tensor models because, with T/S=7‚Å¢(1-n)ùëáùëÜ71ùëõitalic-T MULOP:divide italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:7 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-n CLOSE:)T/S=7(1-n), decreasing nùëõitalic-nn also increases the contribution of gravity waves to the observed COBE anisotropies and therefore reduces the implied amplitude of the (scalar) matter fluctuations. Since fluctuations in the baryon component can only grow after the baryons decouple from the photons, increasing Bùêµitalic-BB depresses and steepens P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) on small scales and therefore reduces Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}) and ŒΩùúàitalic-nu
u. However, for our adopted parameters the baryons always contribute a small fraction of the overall mass density, so the influence of Œ©bsubscriptŒ©ùëèOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{b} changes is small. Increasing Œ©ŒΩsubscriptŒ©ùúàOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{
u} in the CHDM model has a much greater effect in the same direction, since the suppression of small scale power by neutrino free streaming is much greater than the suppression by baryon-photon coupling.

Figures¬†2 and¬†3 re-emphasize the point made earlier in our discussion of Figure¬†1: the agreement between the predicted and measured slope of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) confirms a general prediction of the inflationary CDM scenario. Although the four fiducial models correspond to quite different versions of this scenario, all of them reproduce the measured value of ŒΩ=-2.25ùúà2.25italic-nu RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.25
u=-2.25 to well within its 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainty once the value of nùëõitalic-nn is chosen to match the measured Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}). However, if the measured value of ŒΩùúàitalic-nu
u had been substantially different, e.g.¬†implying ŒΩ>-2ùúà2italic-nu RELOP:greater-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2
u>-2 or ŒΩ<-2.5ùúà2.5italic-nu RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.5
u<-2.5, then none of these models could have reproduced the measured ŒΩùúàitalic-nu
u while remaining consistent with the measured Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}), even allowing changes in nùëõitalic-nn, Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, h‚Ñéitalic-hh, Œ©ŒΩsubscriptŒ©ùúàOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{
u}}, or Œ©bsubscriptŒ©ùëèOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{b}}. A different value of ŒΩùúàitalic-nu
u would therefore have been a challenge to the inflationary CDM scenario itself rather than to any specific version of it. Note also that any of the models would match the observed ŒΩùúàitalic-nu
u within its 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainty even if we had assumed a scale-invariant, n=1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1 inflationary spectrum; it is the Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}) measurement that requires the departures from n=1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1. Because of the long lever arm from COBE to the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), parameter changes that have a modest effect on ŒΩùúàitalic-nu
u have a large effect on Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}).

Figure¬†2 also shows that changes of the different model parameters have nearly degenerate effects on the predicted values of Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}) and ŒΩùúàitalic-nu\nu. For example, in the ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM model, increasing Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} by 0.1 would increase the predicted slope and amplitude, but decreasing h‚Ñéitalic-hh by 0.05 would almost exactly cancel this change. This near degeneracy allows us to summarize the constraints imposed by COBE and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) with simple formulas of the form

Table¬†2 lists the values of Œ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha, Œ≤ùõΩitalic-beta\beta, Œ≥ùõæitalic-gamma\gamma, kùëòitalic-kk, and œµitalic-œµitalic-epsilon\epsilon for all of the fiducial models. Although we do not show Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} changes for the TCDM models in Figure¬†2, we vary it below 1.01.0NUMBER:1.01.0 (adding Œ©ŒõsubscriptŒ©ŒõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{\Lambda}} to keep the universe flat) in order to derive the Œ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha, Œ≤ùõΩitalic-beta\beta, and Œ≥ùõæitalic-gamma\gamma indices, so that in all models their values reflect the importance of a change in h‚Ñéitalic-hh, nùëõitalic-nn, or Bùêµitalic-BB relative to a change in Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}.

Equation¬†(7), together with Table¬†2, is our second principal result, defining the quantitative constraints placed on the parameters of inflationary CDM models by the combination of COBE and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). The values of the Œ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha, Œ≤ùõΩitalic-beta\beta, and Œ≥ùõæitalic-gamma\gamma indices reflect the sensitivity of the predicted power spectrum amplitude Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}) to the model parameters, quantifying the impressions from Figure¬†2. Again taking ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM as an example, we see that small variations in h‚Ñéitalic-hh and nùëõitalic-nn have much greater effect than small variations in Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, and that the suppression of small scale power from increases in Bùêµitalic-BB is always a modest effect. Models with tensors are much more sensitive to nùëõitalic-nn than models without tensors because of the influence of gravity waves on the P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) normalization, as discussed above. Although the index values are derived in all cases by considering small variations about the corresponding fiducial model, the constraint formula¬†(7) remains accurate even for fairly large changes in the cosmological parameters. For example, plugging the TCDM values of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, h‚Ñéitalic-hh, nùëõitalic-nn, Bùêµitalic-BB into equation¬†(7) with the ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM values of Œ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha, Œ≤ùõΩitalic-beta\beta, and Œ≥ùõæitalic-gamma\gamma yields k=0.47ùëò0.47italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.47k=0.47, compared to the value k=0.44ùëò0.44italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.44k=0.44 listed for ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM in Table¬†2.

div.p: with parameters also listed in Table¬†1. However, this equation cannot describe the results of Figure¬†3 as accurately as equation¬†(7) describes the results of Figure¬†2.

Recently McDonald et al.¬†(2000) measured the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest flux power spectrum in a sample of eight Keck HIRES spectra and used it to infer the amplitude and shape of the mass power spectrum. Their mean absorption redshift is z‚âà3ùëß3italic-z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:3z\approx 3 rather than z=2.5ùëß2.5italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5z=2.5, and their data best constrain the P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) amplitude at k=0.04‚Å¢(km‚Å¢s-1)-1ùëò0.04superscriptkmsuperscripts11italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.04 OPEN:( km s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk=0.04\;({\rm{km\;s^{-1}\;}})^{-1} rather than 0.008‚Å¢(km‚Å¢s-1)-10.008superscriptkmsuperscripts11NUMBER:0.008 OPEN:( km s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0.008\;({\rm{km\;s^{-1}\;}})^{-1}. However, assuming gravitational instability and a CDM power spectrum shape, they extrapolate from their result to derive values of ŒΩùúàitalic-nu\nu and Œî2superscriptŒî2Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta^{2} that can be directly compared to CWPHK‚Äôs measurement at z=2.5ùëß2.5italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5z=2.5, kp=0.008‚Å¢(km‚Å¢s-1)-1subscriptùëòùëù0.008superscriptkmsuperscripts11italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.008 OPEN:( km s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk_{p}=0.008\;({\rm{km\;s^{-1}\;}})^{-1}, obtaining ŒΩ=-2.24¬±0.10ùúàplus-or-minus2.240.10italic-nu RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.24 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.10\nu=-2.24\pm 0.10 and Œî2‚Å¢(kp)=0.32¬±0.07superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùplus-or-minus0.320.07Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.32 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.07\Delta^{2}(k_{p})=0.32\pm 0.07. Despite the entirely independent data sets and very different modelling procedures, the CWPHK and McDonald et al.¬†(2000) measurements agree almost perfectly in slope and are consistent in amplitude at the ‚àº1‚Å¢œÉsimilar-toabsent1ùúéRELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 italic-sigma\sim 1\sigma level. We plot the McDonald et al.¬†(2000) measurement as error crosses in Figures¬†2 and¬†3. McDonald et al.¬†(2000) note that the small error bar on Œî2superscriptŒî2Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta^{2} should be considered preliminary, since they have not fully investigated the sensitivity of their power spectrum normalization procedure to their modelling assumptions.

Clearly none of our qualitative conclusions about inflationary CDM models would change if we were to adopt the McDonald et al.¬†(2000) P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) determination instead of the CWPHK determination. Conveniently, the McDonald et al.¬†(2000) point lies almost exactly on our -1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 italic-sigma-1\sigma error contour, so to a good approximation one can obtain the parameter constraints¬†(7) and¬†(8) implied by the McDonald et al.¬†(2000) measurement by simply replacing the values of kùëòitalic-kk in Table¬†2 by k-œµùëòitalic-œµitalic-k ADDOP:minus italic-epsilonk-\epsilon.

We have shown that the combination of COBE and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) yields constraints on degenerate combinations of cosmological parameters. To break these degeneracies, we now consider observational constraints from other studies of large scale structure and CMB anisotropies. Analyses of cosmological parameter constraints from multiple observations have been carried out by numerous groups (recent examples include bahcall99 ; bridle99 ; Steigman (Hata); novosyadlyj00 ; Wang (Tegmark)). Our new contribution is to include the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) as one of the observational constraints (also considered by novosyadlyj00 and Wang (Tegmark)). We focus our attention on several other constraints that can be cast into a form that complements our results from Section 3: the mass function of galaxy clusters, the mass power spectrum inferred from galaxy peculiar velocities, the shape parameter of the galaxy power spectrum, and a constraint on nùëõitalic-nn from CMB anisotropy data. Our discussion in this Section will be more qualitative than our discussion in Section 3, in part because the uncertainties in these constraints are largely systematic, so that a straightforward statistical combination could be misleading.

In each panel of Figures¬†4 and¬†5, the heavy solid line shows the locus of (Œ©m,n)subscriptŒ©ùëöùëõOPEN:( Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-n CLOSE:)({\Omega_{m}},n) values that yield a simultaneous match to COBE and the CWPHK measurement of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). These lines are very close to those implied by equation¬†(7) and Table¬†2, but since those results are, strictly speaking, expansions about our fiducial model parameters, we compute the best-fit value of nùëõitalic-nn exactly for each Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} rather than using equation¬†(7). The ¬±1‚Å¢œÉplus-or-minus1ùúéADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1 italic-sigma\pm 1\sigma constraints are shown as the lighter solid lines; these are close to the curves implied by equation¬†(7) and Table¬†2 with kùëòitalic-kk replaced by k¬±œµplus-or-minusùëòitalic-œµitalic-k ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-epsilonk\pm\epsilon. Because the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraint is not very sensitive to Bùêµitalic-BB, we keep Bùêµitalic-BB fixed at our fiducial value of 0.02 in all cases. We show results for h=0.65‚Ñé0.65italic-h RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.65h=0.65, h=0.45‚Ñé0.45italic-h RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.45h=0.45, and h=0.85‚Ñé0.85italic-h RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.85h=0.85 in the upper, middle, and lower panels of each figure, with flat and open models in the left and right hand columns, respectively. Figure¬†4 shows models without tensors and Figure¬†5 models with tensors. For models with tensors, we restrict the parameter space to n‚â§1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1n\leq 1, since our assumption that T/S=7‚Å¢(1-n)ùëáùëÜ71ùëõitalic-T MULOP:divide italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:7 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-n CLOSE:)T/S=7(1-n) only makes sense in this regime. The TCDM models can be considered as the limit of either the flat or open models at Œ©m=1subscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}=1. Note that the McDonald et al. (2000) estimate of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) corresponds very closely to our -1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 italic-sigma-1\sigma constraint, so to adopt McDonald et al.¬†(2000) instead of CWPHK one simply follows the lower solid line instead of the middle solid line as the constraint.

div.p: For Gaussian initial conditions, the space density of clusters as a function of virial mass constrains a combination of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} and the mass fluctuation amplitude, since clusters of a given mass can be formed by the collapse of large volumes in a low density universe or smaller volumes in a higher density universe. This constraint can be summarized quite accurately in a formula relating Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} to the rms mass fluctuation œÉ8subscriptùúé8italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{8} (White (Efstathiou)). We use the specific version of this formula obtained by Eke, Cole, & Frenk (1996, hereafter ECF) using N-body simulations and the Press-Schechter (1974) approximation:

CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

div.p: For each value of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, we find the value of œÉ8subscriptùúé8italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{8} required by the cluster mass function from equation¬†(9). Given h‚Ñéitalic-hh and B=0.02ùêµ0.02italic-B RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.02B=0.02, we then find the value of nùëõitalic-nn required to produce this value of œÉ8subscriptùúé8italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{8} by numerically integrating the CDM power spectrum. This constraint in the Œ©m-nsubscriptŒ©ùëöùëõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-n{\Omega_{m}}-n plane is shown by the dotted line in each panel of Figures¬†4 and¬†5, with an error bar that indicates the 8% uncertainty quoted in equation¬†(9) from ECF.

For a given value of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, the matter power spectrum can also be estimated from the statistics of galaxy peculiar motions. Freudling et al.¬†(1998) apply a maximum likelihood technique to the SFI peculiar velocity catalog to constrain COBE-normalized, inflationary CDM models for the matter power spectrum, obtaining the constraint

div.p: where Œºùúáitalic-mu\mu, ŒΩùúàitalic-nu\nu, kùëòitalic-kk and œµitalic-œµitalic-epsilon\epsilon are dependent on the cosmology and h60‚â°h/0.6subscript‚Ñé60‚Ñé0.6italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-h MULOP:divide NUMBER:0.6h_{60}\equiv h/0.6. In a flat, Œ©Œõ=1-Œ©msubscriptŒ©Œõ1subscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{\Lambda}}=1-{\Omega_{m}} model with no tensor component, (Œºùúáitalic-mu\mu, ŒΩùúàitalic-nu\nu, kùëòitalic-kk, œµitalic-œµitalic-epsilon\epsilon)=(1.3, 2.0, 0.58, 0.08), while if a tensor component is allowed they become (1.3, 3.9, 0.58, 0.08). For an open, Œ©Œõ=0subscriptŒ©Œõ0Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0{\Omega_{\Lambda}}=0 model without a tensor component they are (0.9, 1.4, 0.68, 0.07). Freudling et al.¬†(1998) do not consider open, Œ©Œõ=0subscriptŒ©Œõ0Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0{\Omega_{\Lambda}}=0 cases with a tensor component. For specified h‚Ñéitalic-hh, equation¬†(10) yields a constraint in the Œ©m-nsubscriptŒ©ùëöùëõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-n{\Omega_{m}}-n plane, shown by the short-dashed line in the panels of Figures¬†4 and¬†5. The associated 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma error bars are based on the statistical uncertainties œµitalic-œµitalic-epsilon\epsilon quoted by Freudling et al.¬†(1998) and listed above. For brevity, we will refer to these curves as the velocity power spectrum constraint, though they represent the constraints on the density power spectrum implied by peculiar velocites.

We do not want to use the amplitude of the galaxy power spectrum as one of our constraints because it can be strongly affected by biased galaxy formation. However, a variety of analytic and numerical arguments (e.g., coles93 ; fry93 ; Mann (Peacock); scherrer98 ; Narayanan (Berlind)) suggest that biased galaxy formation should not alter the shape of the galaxy power spectrum on scales in the linear regime, and on these scales the shape is directly related to the parameters of the inflationary CDM cosmology. We adopt the specific constraint found by Peacock & Dodds (1994) from their combined analysis of a number of galaxy clustering data sets:

div.p: For n=1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1, Œìeff=ŒìsubscriptŒìeffŒìGamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals Gamma\Gamma_{\rm eff}=\Gamma, where ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma is the shape parameter in the conventional parameterization of the inflationary CDM power spectrum (bardeen86 ; the influence of Œ©bsubscriptŒ©ùëèOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{b}} is discussed by sugiyama95 ). While the effects of ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma and nùëõitalic-nn on the power spectrum shape are different, equation¬†(11) combines them in a way that approximates their nearly degenerate influence over the range of scales currently probed by large scale clustering measurements. For specified h‚Ñéitalic-hh and Bùêµitalic-BB, equation¬†(11) becomes a constraint in the Œ©m-nsubscriptŒ©ùëöùëõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-n{\Omega_{m}}-n plane. We plot this constraint as the long-dashed line and associated error bar in the panels of Figures¬†4 and¬†5. We should note, however, that the Peacock & Dodds (1994) error bar may be overoptimistic, since independent estimates of ŒìeffsubscriptŒìeffGamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Gamma_{\rm eff} often fall outside this range. Eisenstein & Zaldarriaga (2001) have recently re-examined the spatial power spectrum inferred from the APM survey and conclude that the 68% confidence interval of ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma (for n=1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1) is 0.19-0.370.190.37NUMBER:0.19 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.370.19-0.37, much larger than the range implied by equation¬†(11), and Efstathiou & Moody (2000) favor a lower central value (Œì‚âà0.12Œì0.12Gamma RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.12\Gamma\approx 0.12, with 2‚Å¢œÉ2ùúéNUMBER:2 italic-sigma2\sigma range 0.05‚â§Œì‚â§0.380.05Œì0.38NUMBER:0.05 RELOP:less-than-or-equals Gamma RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.380.05\leq\Gamma\leq 0.38). As older estimates of the galaxy power spectrum are supplanted by results from the 2dF and Sloan galaxy redshift surveys, the ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma parameterization itself may become an insufficiently accurate representation of the theoretical predictions (percival01 ).

A detailed consideration of constraints from smaller scale CMB anisotropy measurements is beyond the scope of this paper, but we do want to draw on limits that smaller scale measurements place on the inflationary index nùëõitalic-nn. For the no-tensor models, we adopt the ‚Äúweak prior‚Äù constraint n=0.96-0.09+0.10ùëõsubscriptsuperscript0.960.100.09italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.96 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.09 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn=0.96^{+0.10}_{-0.09} of Netterfield et al.¬†(2001), based on data from the BOOMERANG experiment, which we represent by the horizontal dot-dash line and 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma error bar in Figure¬†4. Since Netterfield et al. (2001) do not consider models with tensor fluctuations, we take the corresponding constraint for the tensor models in Figure¬†5 from Wang et al. (2001). Their model space is less restrictive than ours because they do not impose the power-law inflation relation T/S=7‚Å¢(1-n)ùëáùëÜ71ùëõitalic-T MULOP:divide italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:7 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-n CLOSE:)T/S=7(1-n), and using CMB data alone they find only a very weak constraint on nùëõitalic-nn. We therefore adopt their constraint from the combination of CMB and large scale structure data, n=0.91-0.05+0.07ùëõsubscriptsuperscript0.910.070.05italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.91 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.07 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.05 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn=0.91^{+0.07}_{-0.05}, where we have reduced the 95% confidence range quoted in their table¬†2 by a factor of two to get a representative 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainty.

In Figures¬†4 and¬†5, the cluster mass function, velocity power spectrum, and shape parameter constraints tend to be roughly parallel to each other, with the shape parameter following a somewhat different track when tensor fluctuations are important. The shape parameter constraint is usually compatible with the cluster mass function constraint, at least if one allows for the possibility that the error bar in equation¬†(11) is somewhat too small. However, the velocity power spectrum always implies a higher fluctuation amplitude than the cluster mass function, and the two constraints are not consistent within their stated 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainties for any combination of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, nùëõitalic-nn, and h‚Ñéitalic-hh. A recent analysis by Silberman et al. (2001) shows that the discrepancy is probably a result of non-linear effects on the velocity power spectrum, and that correcting for these yields results closer to the cluster constraint. We therefore regard the cluster constraint as more reliable, and we retain the velocity power spectrum curve mainly as a reminder of other data that can be brought to bear on these questions.

The LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) curve cuts across the other three constraints, requiring greater change in Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} for a given change in nùëõitalic-nn. The CMB anisotropy limit on nùëõitalic-nn cuts across all of the other constraints. The COBE-DMR measurement is represented implicitly in Figures¬†4 and¬†5 through its role in the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraint, the velocity power spectrum constraint, and the CMB anisotropy constraint on nùëõitalic-nn. The size of the 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma error bars in these figures, and the probability that at least some of them are underestimated, prevents us from drawing sweeping conclusions. However, Figures¬†4 and¬†5 do have a number of suggestive implications if we look for models that lie within the overlapping 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainties of the various constraints. Since it is not possible to satisfy the cluster mass function and velocity power spectrum constraints simultaneously within the class of models that we consider, the implications depend strongly on which of these constraints we take to be more reliable. The shape parameter implications are usually intermediate, but significantly closer to those of the cluster mass function.

The combination of the velocity power spectrum and LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraints implies a high density universe, with Œ©m‚â≥1greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:1\Omega_{m}\gtrsim 1 preferred and Œ©m‚â≤0.6less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptŒ©ùëö0.6Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:0.6\Omega_{m}\lesssim 0.6 separating the two constraints by more than their 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma error bars. The LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraint rules out the high values of nùëõitalic-nn that could otherwise allow low Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{m} in equation¬†(10). For h‚â•0.65‚Ñé0.65italic-h RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.65h\geq 0.65, intersection of the velocity power spectrum and LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraints occurs at n‚â≤0.8less-than-or-similar-toùëõ0.8italic-n RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:0.8n\lesssim 0.8, incompatible with the CMB anisotropy constraint. However, an Œ©m‚àº1similar-tosubscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}\sim 1 universe would require a low value of h‚Ñéitalic-hh in any case because of the age constraint for globular cluster stars, and this would push the intersection to higher nùëõitalic-nn. As noted earlier, the velocity power spectrum constraint shown here is probably biased towards high Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{m} by the non-linear effects described by Silberman et al. (2001).

If we instead adopt the cluster mass function constraint, then consistency with the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) and COBE requires Œ©m<1subscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1\Omega_{m}<1. For h=0.65‚Ñé0.65italic-h RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.65h=0.65, the constraints intersect at Œ©m‚àº0.4-0.5similar-tosubscriptŒ©ùëö0.40.5Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.5{\Omega_{m}}\sim 0.4-0.5 in flat models and Œ©m‚àº0.5-0.6similar-tosubscriptŒ©ùëö0.50.6Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6{\Omega_{m}}\sim 0.5-0.6 in open models; increasing h‚Ñéitalic-hh slightly decreases the preferred Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} and vice versa. This conclusion ‚Äî that the combination of COBE, the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), and the cluster mass function implies a low density universe ‚Äî is the most important and robust result to emerge from this multi-constraint analysis.

At one level, our conclusions about the matter density come as no suprise, since we have already argued, in Weinberg et al.¬†(1999), that consistency between the cluster mass function and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) implies Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} in this range independent of the COBE normalization. However, the nature of the argument is subtly different in this case. In Weinberg et al.¬†(1999), we considered matter power spectra of the CDM form parameterized by ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma (with n=1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1), and by combining the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) measurement with the cluster constraint¬†(9), we found Œ©m=0.34+1.3‚Å¢(Œì-0.2)subscriptŒ©ùëö0.341.3Œì0.2Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.34 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1.3 OPEN:( Gamma ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.2 CLOSE:){\Omega_{m}}=0.34+1.3(\Gamma-0.2) for flat models and Œ©m=0.46+1.3‚Å¢(Œì-0.2)subscriptŒ©ùëö0.461.3Œì0.2Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.46 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1.3 OPEN:( Gamma ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.2 CLOSE:){\Omega_{m}}=0.46+1.3(\Gamma-0.2) for open models, with 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainties of about 0.10.1NUMBER:0.10.1. However, the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) alone could not rule out the solution of high Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} and high ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma, so Weinberg et al.‚Äôs (1999) conclusion that Œ©m<1subscriptŒ©ùëö1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}<1 rested crucially on the empirical evidence for Œì‚âà0.2Œì0.2Gamma RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.2\Gamma\approx 0.2 from the shape of the galaxy power spectrum. Within the class of CDM models considered here, the combination of COBE and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) determines nùëõitalic-nn, and hence the effective value of ŒìŒìGamma\Gamma (eq.¬†11), once Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, h‚Ñéitalic-hh, and Bùêµitalic-BB are specified. Simultaneous consistency between COBE, the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), and the cluster mass function requires low Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} independent of the galaxy power spectrum shape, thereby strengthening the overall argument for a low density universe, and, by the by, for a matter power spectrum with low ŒìeffsubscriptŒìeffGamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Gamma_{\rm eff}. The lower limit on Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} from this combination of constraints varies with the choice of other parameters, but it never reaches as low as Œ©m=0.2subscriptŒ©ùëö0.2Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2{\Omega_{m}}=0.2 unless h‚â•0.85‚Ñé0.85italic-h RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.85h\geq 0.85.

For all of the models shown in Figures¬†4 and¬†5, the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) and cluster mass function constraints intersect at values of nùëõitalic-nn consistent with the CMB anisotropy constraints, provided one takes the 1-œÉùúéitalic-sigma\sigma error ranges into account. A factor of two improvement in the precision of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) measurement could greatly restrict the range of models compatible with all three constraints, especially if the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) amplitude is somewhat lower, as McDonald et al. (2000) find.

There are, of course, numerous other constraints on cosmological parameters, and we will briefly consider three of them: the cluster baryon fraction, the location of the first acoustic peak in the CMB power spectrum, and the evidence for accelerating expansion from Type Ia supernovae. (Our focus on h=0.65‚Ñé0.65italic-h RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.65h=0.65 as a fiducial case already reflects our assessment of the most convincing direct estimates of H0subscriptùêª0italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{0}.) If one assumes that baryons are not overrepresented relative to their universal value within the virial radii of rich clusters, then the combination of the measured gas mass fractions with big bang nucleosynthesis limits on Œ©bsubscriptŒ©ùëèOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{b} yields an upper limit on Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} (white93b ). Applying this argument, Evrard (1997) concludes that

semantics.annotation: Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:23.1 ARROW:Longrightarrow Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.57 OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-B ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:0.02 ARG:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-h ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:0.65 ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: at the 95% confidence level. From Figures¬†4 and¬†5 we see that models matching COBE, the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), and the cluster mass function are always consistent with this limit ‚Äî easily in the case of flat models, sometimes marginally in the case of open models. Models that match the velocity power spectrum instead of the cluster mass function are usually incompatible with this limit, though sometimes only marginally so.

The location of the first acoustic peak in the CMB anisotropy spectrum is a strong diagnostic for space curvature (e.g., Doroshkevich (Zeldovich); wilson81 ; sugiyama92 ; Kamionkowski (Spergel); Hu et al.¬†1997), and recent anisotropy measurements on degree scales favor a geometry that is close to flat (e.g., miller99 ; melchiorri00 ; netterfield01 ; pryke01 ). Clearly our flat universe models are compatible with these results, as are the open universe models that match the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) and the velocity power spectrum (all of which have Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} close to one). The open models that match LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) and the cluster mass function are generally ruled out by the most recent, high precision limits on space curvature. The Type Ia supernova measurements of the cosmic expansion history (riess98 ; perlmutter99 ) add a great deal of discriminatory power, since they constrain a parameter combination that is roughly Œ©m-Œ©ŒõsubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ©ŒõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}-{\Omega_{\Lambda}} instead of Œ©m+Œ©ŒõsubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ©ŒõOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}+{\Omega_{\Lambda}}; Perlmutter et al.¬†(1999) quote Œ©m-0.75‚Å¢Œ©Œõ‚âà-0.25¬±0.125subscriptŒ©ùëö0.75subscriptŒ©Œõplus-or-minus0.250.125Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.75 Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.25 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.125{\Omega_{m}}-0.75{\Omega_{\Lambda}}\approx-0.25\pm 0.125. All of the open models miss this constraint by many œÉùúéitalic-sigma\sigma, and the flat models matching the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) and the velocity power spectrum fail because the values of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} are too high. The combination of COBE, the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), and the cluster mass function, on the other hand, is compatible with the supernova results for flat models with a cosmological constant, though it favors somewhat higher values of Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}.

Figure 6:
CMB anisotropy power spectra for five of the fiducial models that match COBE-DMR and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). Clsubscriptùê∂ùëôitalic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{l} is the mean-squared amplitude of spherical harmonics of order lùëôitalic-ll. The models shown are ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM (solid), ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM2 (dotted), OCDM (long-dashed), TCDM (short-dashed), and CHDM (dot-dashed). Parameters of the models are listed in Table¬†1. Data points with 1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma errors are taken from Wang et al. (2001). We shift from logarithmic spacing to linear spacing at l=100ùëô100italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:100l=100 in order to show both large and small angular scales clearly.

div.p: All in all, the CWPHK and McDonald et al.¬†(2000) measurements of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) provide additional support for the current ‚Äúconsensus‚Äù model of structure formation, ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM with Œ©m‚âà0.4subscriptŒ©ùëö0.4Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.4{\Omega_{m}}\approx 0.4 and h‚âà0.65‚Ñé0.65italic-h RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.65h\approx 0.65. Moderate improvements in the statistical precision of the constraints considered here could strengthen this support, or they could open fissures of disagreement. Improvements in the near future could also allow some interesting new tests, such as discriminating between models with no tensor fluctuations and models with the T/S=7‚Å¢(1-n)ùëáùëÜ71ùëõitalic-T MULOP:divide italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:7 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-n CLOSE:)T/S=7(1-n) contribution predicted by power law inflation.

A detailed consideration of the constraints from CMB anisotropy measurements is a major undertaking in itself, well beyond the scope of this paper. However, to illustrate the interplay between our results and recent CMB experiments, we plot in Figure¬†6 the predicted CMB power spectra of five of our fiducial models: ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM, ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM2, OCDM, TCDM, and CHDM. We computed these power spectra using CMBFAST (seljak96 ; Zaldarriaga (Seljak)), with the cosmological parameter values listed in Table¬†1. The CHDM model stands out from the rest because matching the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) requires a high value of nùëõitalic-nn, which boosts the anisotropy on small scales. The OCDM model also stands out, albeit less dramatically, because the open space geometry shifts the acoustic peaks to smaller angles. The TCDM model lies below the ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM models because of its larger tilt, which suppresses small scale fluctuations. Figure¬†6 shows data points taken from the joint analysis of numerous CMB data sets by Wang et al. (2001; see their Table 1). The two ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM models fit these data points remarkably well, given that the choice of their parameters was not based on small scale CMB data at all. Because the combination of COBE and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) implies nùëõitalic-nn close to one for both of these models, their predictions are not very different, and the current CMB data do not distinguish between them. However, the TCDM, OCDM, and CHDM models are clearly ruled out, and while we have not attempted to adjust their parameters within the constraints allowed by equations¬†(7) and¬†(8), it appears unlikely that any such adjustment would allow these models to fit the current CMB data.

The slope of the mass power spectrum inferred by CWPHK from the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest, ŒΩ=-2.25¬±0.18ùúàplus-or-minus2.250.18italic-nu RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.25 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.18
u=-2.25\pm 0.18 at kp=0.008‚Å¢(km‚Å¢s-1)-1subscriptùëòùëù0.008superscriptkmsuperscripts11italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.008 OPEN:( km s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk_{p}=0.008\;({m{km\;s^{-1}\;}})^{-1} at z=2.5ùëß2.5italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5z=2.5, confirms one of the basic predictions of the inflationary CDM scenario: an approximately scale-invariant spectrum of primeval inflationary fluctuations (n‚âà1ùëõ1italic-n RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1n\approx 1) modulated by a transfer function that bends the power spectrum towards P‚Å¢(k)‚àùkn-4proportional-toùëÉùëòsuperscriptùëòùëõ4italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:) RELOP:proportional-to italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP(k)\propto k^{n-4} on small scales. If the measured slope of the power spectrum had implied ŒΩ>-2ùúà2italic-nu RELOP:greater-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2
u>-2 or ŒΩ<-2.5ùúà2.5italic-nu RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.5
u<-2.5, we would have been unable to reproduce the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) with any of the models considered here, even allowing wide variations in the cosmological parameters.

Because the amplitude of the COBE-normalized power spectrum on small scales is very sensitive to nùëõitalic-nn, we are able to match the CWPHK measurement of Œî2‚Å¢(kp)superscriptŒî2subscriptùëòùëùDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}) in most of the major variants of the CDM scenario (ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM, OCDM, TCDM, CHDM) by treating nùëõitalic-nn as a free parameter. Within each of these variants, we obtain constraints on the model parameters of the form Œ©m‚Å¢hŒ±‚Å¢nŒ≤‚Å¢BŒ≥=k¬±œµsubscriptŒ©ùëösuperscript‚ÑéùõºsuperscriptùëõùõΩsuperscriptùêµùõæplus-or-minusùëòitalic-œµOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-B POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-k ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-epsilon{\Omega_{m}}h^{\alpha}n^{\beta}B^{\gamma}=k\pm\epsilon (eq.¬†7) or Œ©m‚Å¢hŒ±‚Å¢nŒ≤‚Å¢BŒ≥‚Å¢Œ©ŒΩŒ¥=k¬±œµsubscriptŒ©ùëösuperscript‚ÑéùõºsuperscriptùëõùõΩsuperscriptùêµùõæsuperscriptsubscriptŒ©ùúàùõøplus-or-minusùëòitalic-œµOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-B POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-k ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-epsilon{\Omega_{m}}h^{\alpha}n^{\beta}B^{\gamma}{\Omega_{\nu}}^{\delta}=k\pm\epsilon (eq.¬†8), with the parameter values listed in Table¬†2. These constraints, together with the confirmation of the predicted slope, are the main results to emerge from combining the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) measurement with the COBE-DMR result.

As shown in Figures¬†4 and¬†5, the parameter combination constrained by COBE and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) is different from the combinations constrained by other measurements of large scale structure and CMB anisotropy, so joint consideration of these constraints can break some of the degeneracies among the fundamental parameters. If we combine the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraint with the constraint on Œ©msubscriptŒ©ùëöOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} and œÉ8subscriptùúé8italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{8} inferred from the cluster mass function (White et al.¬†1993a; ECF), then we favor a low density universe, with Œ©m‚àº0.3-0.5similar-tosubscriptŒ©ùëö0.30.5Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.5{\Omega_{m}}\sim 0.3-0.5 in flat models and Œ©m‚àº0.5-0.6similar-tosubscriptŒ©ùëö0.50.6Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6{\Omega_{m}}\sim 0.5-0.6 in open models. This combination is also consistent with CMB anisotropy constraints on nùëõitalic-nn. The open models are inconsistent with the angular location of the first acoustic peak in the CMB power spectrum (netterfield01 ; pryke01 ), and they are strongly inconsistent with Type Ia supernova results, which imply Œ©m-0.75‚Å¢Œ©Œõ‚âà-0.25¬±0.125subscriptŒ©ùëö0.75subscriptŒ©Œõplus-or-minus0.250.125Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.75 Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.25 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.125{\Omega_{m}}-0.75{\Omega_{\Lambda}}\approx-0.25\pm 0.125 (riess98 ; perlmutter99 ). The flat models are consistent with both constraints. On the whole, the CWPHK measurement of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) supports the consensus in favor of ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM with Œ©m‚âà0.4subscriptŒ©ùëö0.4Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.4{\Omega_{m}}\approx 0.4, h‚âà0.65‚Ñé0.65italic-h RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.65h\approx 0.65. The contribution of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) to this consensus comes both from the slope, which confirms the generic inflationary CDM prediction, and from the amplitude, which has a different dependence on cosmological parameters than any of the other constraints considered here.

There are bright prospects for improvements of this approach in the near future. McDonald et al.¬†(2000) have inferred the mass power spectrum from an independent LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†forest data set using a different analysis method, obtaining a nearly identical slope and an amplitude lower by ‚àº1‚Å¢œÉsimilar-toabsent1ùúéRELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 italic-sigma\sim 1\sigma. We have recently analyzed a much larger data set of high and moderate resolution spectra, using a variant of the Croft et al.¬†(1998, 1999) method, and the improved data yield much higher statistical precision and better tests for systematic effects. Constraints from this new measurement of P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), using the method developed here, are presented in ¬ß7 of Croft et al. (2001). Recent measurements of CMB anisotropy have greatly improved the level of precision on small angular scales, and results from the MAP satellite should provide another major advance in the near future. These measurements yield tighter cosmological parameter constraints on their own, but they become substantially more powerful when combined with data that constrain the shape and amplitude of the matter power spectrum. It is evident from Figures¬†4 and¬†5 that simply reducing the error bars on nùëõitalic-nn and the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha¬†P‚Å¢(k)ùëÉùëòitalic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) by a factor of two would already produce interesting new restrictions on the allowable range of models. These restrictions can become very powerful if ongoing studies of cluster masses using galaxy dynamics, X-ray properties, the Sunyaev-Zel‚Äôdovich effect, and gravitational lensing confirm the robustness of the cluster mass function constraint. In the slightly longer term, the 2dF and Sloan redshift surveys should produce measurements of the shape of the galaxy power spectrum that shrink the current statistical and systematic uncertainties, so that demanding consistency between the inferred value of ŒìeffsubscriptŒìeffGamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Gamma_{\rm eff} and other constraints becomes a useful additional test. At the very least, these developments should lead to a powerful test of the inflationary CDM picture and high-precision determinations of its parameters. If we are lucky, improved measurements will reveal deficiencies of the simplest ŒõŒõLambda\LambdaCDM models that are hidden within the current uncertainties, and resolving these discrepancies will lead us to a better understanding of the cosmic energy contents and the origin of primordial fluctuations in the hot early universe.
